title: Progressive Bilateral Sensorineural Hearing Loss with History of Trauma
chief_complaint: I've had hearing loss for several years and it seems to be getting worse. My hearing aids are over 10 years old. I do okay talking one-on-one in quiet places, so I try to conduct my business meetings in quiet areas.

problem_summary.associated_symptoms: History of trauma to the right ear (water skiing fall).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Able to converse one-on-one in quiet; restricts business activities to quiet environments to compensate.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation; currently wears BTE aids >10 years old.

history.present_illness: Patient reports long-standing, progressive bilateral hearing loss.
history.otologic_history: Attributed to family history and trauma to the right ear (fall while water skiing). No other otologic symptoms reported.
history.noise_exposure_history: Not significantly noted, other than trauma event.
history.prior_management: Wears bilateral BTE hearing aids (>10 years old).
history.patient_goals: Conducts business in quiet areas; looking to assess current status.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows severe sloping to profound sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL). Left ear shows moderate sloping to severe (250-1500 Hz) then profound (2000-8000 Hz) SNHL. No measurable responses at 6-8 kHz bilaterally. Right ear BC thresholds at 250-1000 Hz noted as vibrotactile.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear speech discrimination could not be tested (CNT) due to severity; only a Speech Awareness Threshold (SAT) was obtained. Left ear showed very poor word recognition ability.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes absent/artifact. Left ipsilateral present at 500 Hz only; absent 1000-4000 Hz. Left contralateral absent.

tests.name: Acoustic reflex decay
tests.key_findings: Could not be measured due to artifact.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a progressive, bilateral, asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, significantly worse in the right ear (severe-to-profound) compared to the left (moderate-to-profound). Speech understanding is critically compromised; the right ear has no measurable word recognition (only awareness), and the left ear has very poor recognition (16%). Middle ear function is normal, but the severity of the loss precludes most acoustic reflex responses.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is severe to profound, particularly in the right ear where speech clarity is extremely limited.
Because your word recognition score in the better ear is very low (16%), traditional hearing aids may provide volume but might not provide enough clarity for speech understanding.
We should discuss a Cochlear Implant evaluation as a potential option given the severity of the loss and poor speech scores.
If proceeding with hearing aids, assistive devices like a captioned telephone and using visual cues are essential for communication.
Since you own a business, continue utilizing quiet environments for meetings, as background noise will make communication nearly impossible.
notes_for_actor: You are a business owner who is used to being in control. You have adapted to your hearing loss by strictly controlling your environment (only meeting in quiet places).
You are likely frustrated that your 10-year-old hearing aids aren't working, but you might be hesitant about surgery (Cochlear Implant) initially.
You rely heavily on the 'better' ear (left), but even that one is struggling significantly now.
